content: I've changed "ASCII" to "Unicode" in Goal and Output sections.

These characters are not part of ASCII... So defining the "ASCII" character value is very consistent.

Different languages don't treat the characters equivalently, since they are multi-byte characters.
For example, the sum of character values for "僕は日本語分を話します。"

In Python, it is 239404.
In Ruby, it is 6331 (sums the bytes).
In Perl, it is 6331 (sums the bytes).
In JS, it is 239404.
In C++, it is -2885.
In C#, it is 239404.
In Go, it is 239404.
In Bash, it is 239404.

Only the languages which give 239404 as the answer have a good chance of solving this in Reverse mode. And figuring out how to give the answers needed by the clash will cost a lot of extra time for anyone who isn't coding in these languages.

At the very least this clash needs to have "Reverse" disabled, which I'll do now, since the author hasn't responded to kayou's complaint in 15 days.

How are we supposed to guess the rules in a reverse ? I won a reverse clash with 40%, the code was print(0) ....
Are not the clash supposed to only use ASCII  chars ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very funny, interesting and very different from everything I saw so far during my journey on Codingame. Thanks!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hard for reverse mode but pretty fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Because it's clear and solvable in under 5 mins and sufficiently different from other contributions I have seen
I don't think it will be easy for the reverse mode, but should be fine in the other two.

Very funny!

I'm not sure it's necessary to repeat *obtained by splitting the input string by the characater "分”*, in the output section...

If feel like it's already giving the answer.

Anyway, for a clash of code, I think it would be really entertaining to play with!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun. As mentioned before a few other characters should be fine for any dev :D
